The Elder Kumārakassapa’s Birth Story
“A hundred thousand eons ago,
a leader arose;
The hero who benefits the whole world,
named Padumuttara.
Then, having become a brahmin,
skilled and perfected in the Vedas,
while wandering for my midday rest,
I saw the leader of the world.
Teaching the Four Noble Truths,
awakening the world with its gods;
The foremost in various discourses,
describing it to the great people.
Then, with a joyful mind,🔽having invited the Realised One,
having adorned the pavilion
with various beautiful cloths.
With various jeweled lights,
I fed the community there;
Having fed them for seven days,
with various delicious foods.
With various beautiful flowers,
having worshipped the one with disciples,
at the foot of his feet,
I made a wish for that place.
Then the supreme sage,
whose nature is full of compassion,
said: ‘Look at this excellent bird,
with eyes like lotus flowers.
Full of joy and rapture,
with his body covered in hair;
with a broad face and a smile,
eager for my instruction.
He fell at my feet,
with a single-minded beautiful mind;
he is seeking that place,
with its various stories.
For a hundred thousand eons,
born into the Okkāka family,
with the name Gotama,
he will be a teacher in the world.
He will be an heir to his Dhamma,
a product of the Dhamma from his heart;🔽the disciple of the Teacher,

translated: will be named Kumārakassapa.🔽With his various flower-garlands,
and his wealth of jewels,
he will attain
the foremost of those with various stories.’
Through that good deed,
and through my intention and aspiration,
having given up my human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
Wandering through existence,
like an actor in the middle of a stage,🔽having been born as a deer,
I entered the womb of a doe.
At that time, when I was in the womb,
the Vajjavāras were established;
my mother was killed by Sākha,
and went for refuge to the Nigrodha tree.
By that king of deer,
I was saved from death.
Having given up my life,
he advised me thus at that time.
‘One should only resort to the banyan tree,
not to the branch;
It is better to die in the banyan tree,
than to live in the branch.’
Taught by that king of deer,

Again, in the teaching of the hero Kassapa,
while I was seeking the meaning;
Having climbed the peak of the rock,
I applied myself to the Jina’s teaching.
Now I was born in Rājagaha,
in the family of a merchant;
My mother, who was pregnant,
went forth into homelessness.

He said, ‘Destroy

Now, too, I am favoured
by the lord of sages, the Victor;
My mother, who gave birth to me happily,
is a nun in the nuns’ quarters.
Knowing that, the lord of the earth,
the Kosalan king, sent me away;
By the method of prince-rejection,
and my name is Kumara Kassapa.
Having gone to the Great Kassapa,
I am Kumara Kassapa;🔽Having heard the body is like an anthill,
taught by the Buddha.
Then my mind was liberated,
without grasping, in every way;
Having tamed the one called Pāyāsi,
I attained this foremost (state).
My defilements are burned up,
I live without defilements.
Welcome indeed it was for me,
the Buddha’s instruction has been done.
